paragraphs.text: %md ### Exporting Serialized Models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage This example creates **Oracle Machine Learning** (OML) regression and classification models and exports the models in a serialized format so that they can be used for scoring via **OML Services** REST API. **OML Services** provides REST API endpoints hosted on Oracle Autonomous Database. These endpoints enable the storing of machine learning models along with their metadata and the creation of scoring endpoints for the model. The REST API for **OML Services** supports both in-database **Oracle Machine Learning** models and **ONNX** format models, as well as cognitive text functionality. ### In this example we demonstrate: - Creating Oracle Machine Learning regression and classification models using the **iris** data - Using **DBMS_DATA_MINING.EXPORT_SERMODEL** to export the models from the database to a binary BLOB - Using the **DBMS_CLOUD** package to send the models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring using OML Services Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
Exporting Serialized Models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage

This example creates Oracle Machine Learning (OML) regression and classification models and exports the models in a serialized format so that they can be used for scoring via OML Services REST API. OML Services provides REST API endpoints hosted on Oracle Autonomous Database. These endpoints enable the storing of machine learning models along with their metadata and the creation of scoring endpoints for the model. The REST API for OML Services supports both in-database Oracle Machine Learning models and ONNX format models, as well as cognitive text functionality.

In this example we demonstrate:

  • Creating Oracle Machine Learning regression and classification models using the iris data
  • Using DBMS_DATA_MINING.EXPORT_SERMODEL to export the models from the database to a binary BLOB
  • Using the DBMS_CLOUD package to send the models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring using OML Services

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md


To interact with other cloud services, the Oracle ADB Cloud service provides the **DBMS_CLOUD** package. This enables the database engine to transfer 
and store objects between ADB and Oracle’s Object Storage. Object Storage stores data as objects within buckets, or containers, and are identified with an 
URI having the following format:

    https://objectstorage.region.oraclecloud.com/v1/tenantname/bucketname/objectname

Access to the objects stored within buckets is protected. To access an object in the Oracle ADB Cloud service, one must to provide identification information 
stored into a credential object. Refer to the ADB User's Guide more information on the **DBMS_CLOUD** procedure.
#### [Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse Cloud User's Guide](https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/user/load-data-cloud.html#GUID-07900054-CB65-490A-AF3C-39EF45505802)

msg.data:
To interact with other cloud services, the Oracle ADB Cloud service provides the DBMS_CLOUD package. This enables the database engine to transfer
and store objects between ADB and Oracle’s Object Storage. Object Storage stores data as objects within buckets, or containers, and are identified with an
URI having the following format:

https://objectstorage.region.oraclecloud.com/v1/tenantname/bucketname/objectname

Access to the objects stored within buckets is protected. To access an object in the Oracle ADB Cloud service, one must to provide identification information
stored into a credential object. Refer to the ADB User's Guide more information on the DBMS_CLOUD procedure.

Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse Cloud User's Guide

paragraphs.text:
%md

To start, create a cloud user credential in ADW to connect to Cloud Storage using the **DBMS_CLOUD.CREATE_CREDENTIAL** procedure.
The **CREATE_CREDENTIAL** procedure creates a credential into the current schema. The username and password correspond to the OML user 
account credentials. In this example, we create a cloud credential for user ***OMLUSER*** with password ***PASSWORD***.

msg.data:
To start, create a cloud user credential in ADW to connect to Cloud Storage using the DBMS_CLOUD.CREATE_CREDENTIAL procedure.
The CREATE_CREDENTIAL procedure creates a credential into the current schema. The username and password correspond to the OML user
account credentials. In this example, we create a cloud credential for user OMLUSER with password PASSWORD.

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md

Create the **IRIS_DATA** table and populate the table with CSV data previously saved in Oracle Cloud Object Storage. 
Use **DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA** to pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request (PAR) to the ***file_uri_list*** parameter.  PARs are used to share and upload Object Storage data. 

When you create a PAR, a unique PAR URL is generated. Users with this URL can access the resources identified in the PAR using the **DBMS_CLOUD** procedures and the standard HTTP tools **cURL** and **wget**.  

You can define PARs on both buckets and objects. Bucket PARs can be used to write data into a specific bucket, however object PARs can be used both to read and write data. When creating a PAR you need to specify a PAR name, the resource object or bucket, the authorized operations (read, write, read/write) and the PAR expiration date. 

For example, here is a PAR defined on object **iris.csv** stored in the bucket **MY_DEMO**:

    https://objectstorage.us-phoenix-1.oraclecloud.com/p/1evW9h43H9IjwkrlEJgCwaUZkj87buyNDWTc/n/samplenamespace/b/MY_DEMO/o/iris.csv

Refer to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure documentation for more information on PARs.
#### [Using Pre-Authenticated Requests](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingpreauthenticatedrequests.htm)

msg.data:
Create the IRIS_DATA table and populate the table with CSV data previously saved in Oracle Cloud Object Storage.
Use DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA to pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request (PAR) to the file_uri_list parameter. PARs are used to share and upload Object Storage data.

When you create a PAR, a unique PAR URL is generated. Users with this URL can access the resources identified in the PAR using the DBMS_CLOUD procedures and the standard HTTP tools cURL and wget.

You can define PARs on both buckets and objects. Bucket PARs can be used to write data into a specific bucket, however object PARs can be used both to read and write data. When creating a PAR you need to specify a PAR name, the resource object or bucket, the authorized operations (read, write, read/write) and the PAR expiration date.

For example, here is a PAR defined on object iris.csv stored in the bucket MY_DEMO:

https://objectstorage.us-phoenix-1.oraclecloud.com/p/1evW9h43H9IjwkrlEJgCwaUZkj87buyNDWTc/n/samplenamespace/b/MY_DEMO/o/iris.csv

Refer to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure documentation for more information on PARs.

Using Pre-Authenticated Requests

paragraphs.text:
%script

CREATE TABLE IRIS_DATA (
    SEPAL_LENGTH    number,
    SEPAL_WIDTH     number,
    PETAL_LENGTH    number,
    PETAL_WIDTH     number,
    SPECIES         varchar2(4000)
);

begin
    DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA (credential_name => 'MY_CLOUD_CRED',	
                          table_name => 'IRIS_DATA',
	                      file_uri_list => '<pre-authenticated request here>',		
	                      format => json_object('type' value 'CSV'));	
end;
/

%md

View the ***IRIS_DATA*** table.

msg.data: View the IRIS_DATA table.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Create a procedure **write_serialized_model** to write the model to a serialized BLOB in the data pump directory.

msg.data: Create a procedure write_serialized_model to write the model to a serialized BLOB in the data pump directory.

Procedure WRITE_SERIALIZED_MODEL compiled


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md

Verify that **OMLUSER** user has **DWROLE** for access to the data pump directory.
ADMIN also needs to execute ***GRANT read, write ON DIRECTORY DATA_PUMP_DIR TO OMLUSER;***.

msg.data:
Verify that OMLUSER user has DWROLE for access to the data pump directory.
ADMIN also needs to execute GRANT read, write ON DIRECTORY DATA_PUMP_DIR TO OMLUSER;.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Find ADW data pump directory location

msg.data: Find ADW data pump directory location

paragraphs.text:
%script

SELECT * FROM all_directories where DIRECTORY_NAME = 'DATA_PUMP_DIR';

msg.data:
OWNER   DIRECTORY_NAME   DIRECTORY_PATH                                           ORIGIN_CON_ID   
SYS     DATA_PUMP_DIR    /u03/dbfs/B20D12DF4787DC63E0531A14000A6FFC/data/dpdump                65

paragraphs.text:
%md

Export models **GLM_MODEL** and **CLASS_MODEL** to serialized BLOB objects in the data pump directory as **GLM_MODEL.mod** and **CLASS_MODEL.mod**.

msg.data: Export models GLM_MODEL and CLASS_MODEL to serialized BLOB objects in the data pump directory as GLM_MODEL.mod and CLASS_MODEL.mod.

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md

Verify the serialized models **GLM_MODEL.mod** and **CLASS_MODEL.mod** exist in data pump directory.

msg.data: Verify the serialized models GLM_MODEL.mod and CLASS_MODEL.mod exist in data pump directory.

paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT * FROM DBMS_CLOUD.LIST_FILES('DATA_PUMP_DIR');

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md

Write the serialized models from the ADW data pump directory to Cloud Object Storage using the **DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT** procedure.

The **PUT_OBJECT** procedure stores an object into a bucket. It is overloaded to provide the ability to read data from a BLOB to or from 
a directory object. In other words, it can be used to move data from the database server to a cloud service.
Pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request to the ***object_uri*** parameter.

msg.data:
Write the serialized models from the ADW data pump directory to Cloud Object Storage using the DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT procedure.

The PUT_OBJECT procedure stores an object into a bucket. It is overloaded to provide the ability to read data from a BLOB to or from
a directory object. In other words, it can be used to move data from the database server to a cloud service.
Pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request to the object_uri parameter.

paragraphs.text:
%script

BEGIN
    DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT (credential_name => 'MY_CLOUD_CRED',	
	                       object_uri => '<pre-authenticated request here>',	
	                       directory_name => 'DATA_PUMP_DIR',
	                       file_name => 'GLM_MODEL.mod');	
END;
/

msg.data:
PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%script

BEGIN
    DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT (credential_name => 'MY_CLOUD_DRED',	
	                       object_uri => '<pre-authenticated request here>',	
	                       directory_name => 'DATA_PUMP_DIR',
	                       file_name => 'CLASS_MODEL.mod');	
END;
/

msg.data:
PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.
